Scoop B: Keith Van Horn Lived His NBA Career on His Terms With No¬†Regrets

If you take a poll of players in the NBA that made wearing knee-high socks cool, the list is slim.

Think Glenn Big Dog Robinson, Elliot Perry, Los Angeles Lakers legend Michael Cooper and then there‚Äôs Keith Van Horn.

Click here to check out Keith Van Horn and I chatting on Scoop B Radio.

Van Horn was the first professional athlete that I ever interviewed.

He was a rookie in 1997 as a member of the then-New Jersey Nets and I was a rookie reporter at 12 years old co-hosting Nets Slammin‚Äô Planet with Lynn Wilson and Albert King.

The 2nd pick in the 1997 NBA Draft, Van Horn averaged 16 points and 6.8 rebounds over 575 career games and nine seasons. He retired in 2006 at the age of 30 after playing a reserve role with the Western Conference champion Mavericks.

He says that being a good father was more important. ‚ÄúI needed to provide stability for them and be there for them,‚Äù Van Horn told me by phone.

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt do that playing in the NBA.‚Äù

Van Horn was the second pick in the 1997 NBA Draft, one pick behind the #1 overall pick, Tim Duncan. Duncan had a successful career as a member of the San Antonio Spurs, winning five rings under legendary coach Gregg Popovich. Looking at his career, one could wonder if Van Horn has any regrets. ‚ÄúTim‚Äôs had a great deal of success,‚Äù said Van Horn.

‚ÄúI was fortunate to have the time in the NBA that I did, but I had a timeline. I had to make different decisions in my life.‚Äù

Since retirement, Van Horn has been keeping himself busy in the hoops realm. He‚Äôs the founder and executive director of the Colorado Premier Basketball Club in the Greater Denver area. A 501(c)(3) nonprofit, the hoops program holds basketball camps, leagues and tournaments for kids 3‚Äì19. The club also facilitates training and beginner skills sessions for all levels.
